titleStmt.title: MONOTONICITY, CONVEXITY AND BOUNDS INVOLVING THE BETA AND RAMANUJAN R-FUNCTIONS

analytic.title: MONOTONICITY, CONVEXITY AND BOUNDS INVOLVING THE BETA AND RAMANUJAN R-FUNCTIONS

startPage=-1, endPage=-1, consolidateCitations=0, consolidateHeader=0, consolidateFunders=0, includeRawAffiliations=false, includeRawCitations=false, includeRawCopyrights=false, generateTeiIds=false, generateTeiCoordinates=[], sentenceSegmentation=false, flavor=null

div.p: In the article, we provide several new asymptotical sharp bounds for the functions involving the Beta function and Ramanujan R -functions via the monotonicity and convexity properties of certain combinations defined in terms of polynomials, Beta and Ramanujan Rfunctions.

div.formula: Γ(x) = ∞ 0 t x-1 e -t dt, ψ(x) = Γ (x) Γ(x) .
div.p: In particular, if y = 1x , then we denote
and

From (1.1) and (1.2) we clearly see that both the functions R(x) and B(x) are symmetry with respect to x = 1/2 . Therefore, we only need to assume that x ∈ (0, 1/2] in what follows. It is easy to know that R(1/2) = log 16 by (1.1).
Let a, b, c ∈ R with c = 0, -1, -2, •••. Then the Gaussian hypergeometric function F(a, b; c; x) [1,2,6,7,8,9] is defined by

x n n! (-1 < x < 1), (1.3) where (a, n) denotes the shifted factorial function (a, n) ≡ a(a + 1) •••(a + n -1) for n ∈ N, and (a, 0) = 1 for a = 0 . It is well known that F(a, b; c; x) has wide applications in mathematics and physics, and many elementary and special functions are the particular or limiting cases of the Gaussian hypergeometric function. In particular, if c = a + b , then F(a, b; c; x) is said to be zero-balanced. As the special case of the Gaussian hypergeometric function, the generalized elliptic integral K a (r) [3,5] of the first kind can be expressed by

for r ∈ (0, 1) and a ∈ (0, 1/2]. The Ramanujan R-function and Beta function are closely related to the Guassian hypergeometric function F(a, b; c; x) and the generalized elliptic integral K a (r) of the first kind. For example, F(a, b; a + b; x) satisfies the asymptotic formula [4]
div.formula: B(a, b)F(a, b; a + b; x) + log(1 -x) = R(a, b) + O((1 -x) log(1 -x)) (x → 1),
div.p: and K a (r) has the sharp asymptotical inequalities [20]

for all a ∈ (0, 1/2] and r ∈ (0, 1). More properties for B(x) and R(x) can be found in the literature [2,4,10,13,14,15,16,17,18,20,23], in which they used to study the generalized η k -distortion function η a k (t) and the generalized λ -distortion function λ (a, K) = η a K (1). Recently, the properties and bounds for B(x) and R(x) have attracted the attention of many researchers [17,23]. Qiu, Ma, and Huang [18] found the power series expansions of the function R(x) -B(x) at x = 0 and x = 1/2 , and proved that
div.formula: 2(2c 2n + α 2n-1 )x 2n+1 B(x) -R(x) + 2 n ∑ k=1 c k x k (2c 2n + α 2n-1 )x 2n and (2c 2n+1 + α 2n )x 2n+1 B(x) -R(x) + 2 2n+1 ∑ k=1 c k x k 2(2c 2n+1 + α 2n )x 2(n+1) ,
div.p: where
is the Riemann zeta function.

In [13], Huang, Qiu, and Ma discussed the monotonicity and convexity properties of the functions x(1x)B(x) and R(x)-[1x(1x)]B(x), and discovered new bounds for the complete integral K a (r) of the first kind.
The main purpose of the article is to provide new monotonicity and convexity properties involving the Ramanujan R-function R(x) and Beta function B(x).

div.head: Lemmas and definition
div.p: In order to prove our main results, we need two lemmas and one definition which we present in this section.

div.formula: I ⊆ R if (-1) n f (n) (x) > 0 for all x ∈ I and n = 0, 1, 2, 3 •••. If (-1) n f (n) (x) 0 for all x ∈ I and n = 0, 1, 2, 3 •••, then f is said to be completely monotonic on I .

Let n = 1 . Then inequality (3.3) leads to Corollary 3.3 immediately. COROLLARY 3.3. The double inequality

Next, we present several new properties the function g
